I discovered Perfume Tree's earliest albums from 1992-94 over the apex of the pandemic, and they've become a work-time staple for me.

When I was in my 20s I was obsessed with the bleep-bloops on "Feeler" and "A Lifetime Away", but today I really prefer the surprisingly natural sound on "Dust" et al. Lotsa loops, but *someone* is playing a real bass guitar, somewhere in those layers...

"Nightmare Jacket" is a fine example from this period. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vZVUbtZ5kro

For millions of years, beavers have covered the northern hemisphere, building dams, slowing water, trapping topsoil, creating vast fertile wetlands, replenishing aquifers, reducing floods, providing fire breaks, increasing evaporation, literally teraforming, and changing the climate. While industrial agriculture squanders topsoil, beavers support a sustainable ecosystem.

During the last stream https://youtu.be/eYvGruGHhUE I forgot to check limits on dispatch counts, and of course they are relatively small.

I'd normally just fix it on the next stream but I'm not sure when that's going to be, so I've fixed this off stream - it just requires a tiny separate dispatch to convert the number of commands to the number of groups and to fill the command tail with dummy (no-op) commands.

At least monthly, I think about the time I insisted to a friend that there was a hit pop song, which I heard everywhere in undergrad, where all the lyrics were from a page of James Joyce’s Ulysses. They had no idea what I was on about so I spent about half an hour tracking it down. It’s from 2002 and wasn’t even in the artist’s top 5 songs on Spotify. It has <10k YouTube views. This is the strongest Mandela effect I’ve personally experienced. Anyway here you go https://youtu.be/5RxwLzaei70

title: Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos - Steven Strogatz, Cornell University

last_post.content:
RT @stevenstrogatz@twitter.com

Students taking a first course in nonlinear dynamics and chaos (or anyone curious about the subject): Videos of lectures are freely available. Hope you enjoy them! https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLbN57C5Zdl6j_qJA-pARJnKsmROzPnO9V

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/stevenstrogatz/status/1614958721561669632

So, boston dynamics has put out another video showcasing the Atlas robots, this time having one manipulate a plank of wood to bridge a gap, go retrieve a bag of tools, carry them up some stairs and across the gap, tossing them up onto a platform to a human "construction worker," turning around. knowcking down large box, jumping down onto that box, doing a "sick flip" from that box to the ground, and then turning around giving a thumbs-up.

Everyone should take a look at the BtS video for this one (https://youtu.be/XPVC4IyRTG8); not because it's particularly bias-bracketed or anything— it's still Boston Dynamics trying sell you their "awesome tech"— but rather because their VERY CAREFUL word choices are quite revealing. …These boston dynamics engineers and programmers are all talking AROUND the idea of whether this system is truly autonomous by using words like "we" did such and such, and "wanted to show," and "future research," and terms of art like "predictive programming." All of this provides a kind of obfuscatory cover so people are wowed by Boston Dynamics' capabilities while still letting BD say that they never really "misled" people as to what they're doing in the original video.

So to be clear: This video is NOT the Atlas system autonomously responding to a completely novel situation with no prompting. It IS the result of a lot of hard work, and that work involves a lot of pre-programming and modelling of EXTREMELY similar "likely" situations, with a lot of fuck-ups in the interim, until they get a whole run right enough, and then that's the video they use.

Boston Dynamics is doing a LOT of research into these areas, but the things they've achieved and are planning to work on are not what most people in the public think they are.

Now, that being said, lots of people who thinking about this in terms of what it's going to do to the value of human labour, and I think that overarching question is a very important one. In a better world, what would come to pass is that the jobs dismantled by automation wouldn't matter because we'd all be getting UBI from the taxes levied against the companies which revenues and profits were increased by, again, dismantling humans' jobs. However, as has been noted, the forces of automation are currently controlled by those who want to both a) not have to pay people to work, let alone to just live, AND b) have those same people somehow still continue to pay into consumer capitalism.

We are, as I've said, looking at a post-WORKER economy, not a post-work one.

And this is without getting into the fact that we're not even ACTUALLY looking at a "post-worker" economy! Most "automated" algorithmic tools are still maintained and supported by humans— just humans paid pennies and exploited for their crucial labor; cf., most recently, ChatGPT and Kenyan workers: https://time.com/6247678/openai-chatgpt-kenya-workers/.

At the end of the day, there are still lots of humans involved in the programming, maintenance, and support of Atlas and other Boston Dynamics stuff, but their labour is often intentionally occulted for a bunch of reasons— chief among them, the prospect of selling more units while paying those humans less.

title: New features in dplyr 1.1.0, and an introduction to ivs

last_post.content:
dplyr 1.1.0 is coming very soon!

I recently spoke about it (and the ivs 📦) at the Charlotte #rstats User Group. This presentation highlights a number of exciting new features, including:

- Per-operation grouping with `.by`
- Join enhancements, like inequality joins, rolling joins, and overlap joins
- New functions like `consecutive_id()` and `case_match()`

#archeologie #archaeology #archeodon

Hello all. On this commemoration of what would be the Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s 94th birthday (again: just one week after my own grandma's 94th birthday party!), here's one of the most impactful and important, but still most under-read writings of his whole life:

"Letter From A Birmingham Jail"
https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/sites/mlk/files/letterfrombirmingham_wwcw_0.pdf

Also available in his own voice:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ATPSht6318o

And it's ALSO a great time to remember some of the friendships that made his life what it was.

Have a reflective and restorative day.

New video: Tai-Pan, a 1979 game for the TRS-80 and Apple II, is not just an influential game, but a very well-documented one: the author wrote a book going through this BASIC program line by line, explaining the entire thing.

Today, in Programming Like It's 1979, we take a look at it!

title: Clément Viktorovitch : retraites, une réforme idéologique

last_post.content:
« Cette réforme des #retraites n’a rien de pragmatique : elle est idéologique. L’enjeu, c’est de savoir dans quelle société nous voulons vivre. Et comment nous sommes prêts à y vieillir. »

Retraites : une réforme libérale, chronique de Clément Viktorovitch, qui revient sur deux conceptions opposées de la retraite : le salaire différé (ce qu'elle devient au fil des réformes) vs le salaire continué (comment elle a été pensée initialement) :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IPQes6kRCrk

title: Epic in Scope: Surviving the Long Haul Project

As I've now added a full chapter to my Criminal Law book on Possession (it used to just be a part of the actus reus chapter), I'd like to find a film clip for a review exercise. It should be short (ideally less than 1 minute and 30 seconds) and present an interesting issue of fact/law. Any suggestions? From 2006/7, these 2 beautiful live-coded #GenerativeMusic pieces by Andrew Sorensen have been very inspirational to me. His work on Impromptu (later Extempore) was one of the reasons I became very interested in functional programming & Lisp (Clojure) back in 2010...

Study in Keith:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bq-260NUw5o&t=113s

Stained:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9TIaMRis8J0&t=63s

Both with slow, but epic build ups over 10-15 mins...

Somewhat related observation & question from #genuary2023 contribs to that topic: Even with more tools/langs available now, is interesting generative/coded music generally still a lot harder to pull off for people (i.e. there were much fewer submissions for that topic yesterday), since - even if going fully experimental and ignoring traditions - it somewhat does rely much more on temporal patterns & layers and interactions between those, and an at least basic music-theoretical background? My personal view & experience is that (as a medium) it's much more emotionally rewarding, but also much less forgiving than its visual counterpart if that background is lacking (and that is just the composition side, not even mentioning DSP aspects)...

(Btw. I'm looking at all this from a tool maker POV...)

The thing is, I played 7 RPGs in my first 7 days as a gamer because I was hanging out at a game shop, when stocking lots of RPGs was the norm.

But that wouldn't _necessarily_ work today, depending on the shop. The one I visited last week had a grand total of two RPGs in stock: Dee-Upon-Dee, and Ye Merrye Pathefinder.

Coke or Pepsi. Take your pick.

Like that "both kinds of music" scene in The Blues Brothers. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vS-zEH8YmiM #TTRPG

@palewire that’s new repos? To me, that doesn’t necessarily indicate decline, but could also be saturation (decline in growth). I saw a similar plateau in Jupyter contributions presented at JupyterCon https://youtu.be/O5zpf-dk_sQ explored more here: https://nbviewer.org/github/minrk/jupyter-activity-data/blob/main/plateau.ipynb . A million possible reasons, but there’s lots more ways to do similar things now.

title: Arcade Game: The Pit (1982 Zilec Electronics)

last_post.content:
A shameless bit of self-promotion.

It's 3 years since I got it into my head that I wanted to make a #Spectrum game. I'd done BASIC in my salad days, but never machine code... How hard could it be?

I picked the ancient 1982 arcade game #ThePit, which had never been ported to the Speccy and looked like a good fit. Here's the original:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mTIjYc-ZH-A

I spent a month drowning in ASM, but finally finished it... and here it is:

https://youtu.be/YQeyKqAeEaY?t=128

https://dokdave.itch.io/the-pit

#GameDev

I recorded a brief introduction to the OTTO RecSys competition on Kaggle!

We start with the baseline and build on top of it by progressively adding more advanced ideas:

• co-visitation matrix
• manual reranking
• reranking using a model
• word2vec & matrix factorization for candidate generation and scoring

Meant as a brief introduction both to the OTTO competition and a couple of foundational ideas in RecSys.

Here it is: https://youtu.be/gtPEX_eRAVo

Hope you find it a good watch! 🙂

title: Which countries are historically responsible for climate change?

last_post.content:
Who is responsible for global heating and the climate emergency? Who made it happen?

As you can see from this video, the U.S. is *by far* the country most responsible for poisoning the atmosphere with CO2.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6zP0L69ielU

In recent years, China has been catching up, BUT — we need to remember that they are building all those factories and container ports and roads and mines and airports so they can feed the obscenely huge demands of U.S. consumers.

So, who should pay for climate mitigation, adaptation, and reparations? Obviously, the U.S. must step forward and take the lead. Think it will happen? 🤣

#ClimateCrisis #ClimateJustice
https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-which-countries-are-historically-responsible-for-climate-change/

title: Songs that use Chromatic Mediant chords

last_post.content:
I'm not good enough to figure this out myself. I learned it from Dave Bennett's excellent video on chromatic mediants, which is full of examples:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_8D1F-wIqI

But what's a chromatic mediant? 🤔

'Mediant' just means 'third'. In a chromatic mediant we have two chords, ideally both major triads or both minor triads, that differ by a third and share a note. But what makes it 'chromatic' is that one of these triads is not in the same scale!

(2/n)

title: Tyler Morgan-Wall - Building an Entire City in R: Interactive 3D Data Visualization with Rayrender

last_post.content:
My talk from the @rstatsdc conference was just posted! Watch and learn how to build an entire 3D city in #RStats, using #rayshader and #rayrender. Also see how I used R to re-create a Washington Post dataviz in only a few lines of code, and how to turn your #Dataviz into an animated death star trench run!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8NV5MxcaWR4

We caught up with Richard moulds, the GM of Amazon BraKet - probably the most unusual service in AWS. It's a fully-managed service with APIs for accessing real, live, quantum computers living in cryogenic labs all around the world. https://youtu.be/gFo32NqxorM

What gives Depeche Mode's song Enjoy the Silence that creepy feel?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_G0G1OjM5h0

I just learned one reason: a 'harmonic mediant'. Check out the part at 0:28 where Dave Gahan sings

Words like violence
Break the silence

The first line uses the notes 1 3♭ 5, which form a minor triad. The second uses 3♭ 5♭ 7♭, another minor triad. But while the first chord uses only notes in the minor scale, the second uses one note, 5♭, which is not in that scale!

Creepy!

(1/n)

Tomorrow!
https://youtu.be/gNF4YLPtgfA
